S3.T1.caption: Table 1. Table of Notation
S3.T1.table:
Notation Meaning
 ϵpsubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑝\epsilon_{p} Privacy leakage (Def. 2)
ϵusubscriptitalic-ϵ𝑢\epsilon_{u} Utility loss (Def. 3)
Wk𝒪subscriptsuperscript𝑊𝒪𝑘W^{\mathcal{O}}_{k} Unprotected model information of client k𝑘k
Wk𝒮subscriptsuperscript𝑊𝒮𝑘W^{\mathcal{S}}_{k} Protected model information of client k𝑘k
Pk𝒪subscriptsuperscript𝑃𝒪𝑘P^{\mathcal{O}}_{k} Distribution of unprotected information of client k𝑘k
Pk𝒮subscriptsuperscript𝑃𝒮𝑘P^{\mathcal{S}}_{k} Distribution of protected information of client k𝑘k
Fkℬsubscriptsuperscript𝐹ℬ𝑘F^{\mathcal{B}}_{k} Adversary’s prior belief distribution about the private information of client k𝑘k
Fk𝒜subscriptsuperscript𝐹𝒜𝑘F^{\mathcal{A}}_{k} Adversary’s belief distribution about client k𝑘k after observing the protected information
Fk𝒪subscriptsuperscript𝐹𝒪𝑘F^{\mathcal{O}}_{k} Adversary’s belief distribution about client k𝑘k after observing the unprotected information
JS(⋅||⋅)\text{JS}(\cdot||\cdot) Jensen-Shannon divergence between two distributions
TV(⋅||⋅)\text{TV}(\cdot||\cdot) Total variation distance between two distributions
references: We follow the convention of representing the random variables using uppercase letters such as S𝑆S, representing the particular values they take on using lowercase letters, and representing the support of random variables using copperplate such as s𝑠s and 𝒟𝒟\mathcal{D}. The distributions are represented using uppercase letters such as F𝐹F and P𝑃P, and the probability density functions are represented using lowercase letters such as f𝑓f and p𝑝p. We use fDk​(d)subscript𝑓subscript𝐷𝑘𝑑f_{D_{k}}(d) to represent the value of the probability density function f𝑓f at s𝑠s, and the subindex represents the random variable. We use the notation fDk|Wk​(d|w)subscript𝑓conditionalsubscript𝐷𝑘subscript𝑊𝑘conditional𝑑𝑤f_{D_{k}|W_{k}}(d|w) to represent the conditional density function. For continuous distributions P𝑃P and Q𝑄Q over ℝnsuperscriptℝ𝑛\mathbb{R}^{n}, the Kullback-Leibler divergence is defined as KL(P||Q)=∫p(x)log(p(x)/q(x))dx\text{KL}(P||Q)=\int p(x)\log(p(x)/q(x))dx, where p𝑝p and q𝑞q denote the probability densities of P𝑃P and Q𝑄Q. The Jensen-Shannon divergence is a smoothed version of the Kullback-Leibler divergence, which is defined as JS(P||Q)=12[KL(P,M)+KL(Q,M)]\text{JS}(P||Q)=\frac{1}{2}\left[\text{KL}\left(P,M\right)+\text{KL}\left(Q,M\right)\right], where M=(P+Q)/2𝑀𝑃𝑄2M=(P+Q)/2. The total variation distance between P𝑃P and Q𝑄Q is TV(P||Q)=supA⊂ℝn|P(A)−Q(A)|\text{TV}(P||Q)=\sup_{A\subset\mathbb{R}^{n}}|P(A)-Q(A)|. See Table 1 for detailed descriptions of notations.

S5.T2.caption:
Table 2. Comparison of privacy-utility trade-offs with Bayesian Privacy (BP) and related privacy measurements, namely, Diff. Privacy (DP) (Dwork
et al., 2014), Local DP (LDP) (Duchi
et al., 2013), Bayesian DP (BDP) (Triastcyn and
Faltings, 2020) and Information Privacy (IP) (du Pin Calmon and
Fawaz, 2012).
references:
The section illustrates the comparison of the proposed Bayesian Privacy with respect to Differential Privacy (Dwork
et al., 2014), Bayesian Differential Privacy BDP (Triastcyn and
Faltings, 2020), Local Differential Privacy (Duchi
et al., 2013) and Information Privacy (du Pin Calmon and
Fawaz, 2012). A brief summary of the comparison is summarized in Table 2.
